awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a High-Performance Mass Spectrometer for Atmospheric Ecometabolomics Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemical Instrumentation Programs. Professor James Smith from the University of California Irvine and colleagues Barbara Finlayson-Pitts, Alex Guenther, Sergey Nizkorodov and Celia Faiola are acquiring a high-performance quadrupole mass spectrometer combined with an Orbitrap mass analyzer and equipped with an ultra-high-pressure liquid chromatograph and tandem capabilities. In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species embedded in complex samples. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized into ions and the ions' masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows the structure of molecules in complex mixtures to be studied. An instrument with a liquid chromatograph can separate mixtures of compounds before they reach the mass spectrometer. This mass spectrometer can resolve ions with a precision that allows determination of molecular formulas and provide essential molecular information using tandem mass spectrometric capabilities. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the University and regional area. The instrument broadens participation by involving diverse groups of students in research and research training using this modern analytical technique. This instrument provides opportunities for collaboration between chemists, earth system scientists, and ecologists in studies of the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum and its response to global modifications.


The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts studies of atmospheric phenomena.  The mass spectrometer is used to investigate ecosystem functioning, including specific processes such as cyclic and seasonal natural phenomena known as phenology, succession, and response to biotic and abiotic stresses, as well as the integrated dynamics of ecological response to environmental changes. The instrument also aids researchers exploring a metabolomics approach to understanding the formation and growth of atmospheric particles from the oxidation of biogenic volatile emissions by hydoxo species, ozone, and nitrogen oxide radicals. This instrument is also employed to perform chemical analysis of aerosol particles formed from biomass burning to better understand the processes controlling its formation and atmospheric impacts. Data from this instrument provides information on the relationship between health impacts and the molecular composition, particularly of the organic component, or ambient aerosol particles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This MRI award allowed us to purchase a Thermo Fisher Q Exactive Plus high-resolution mass spectrometer (HRMS) and Vanquish Horizon Ultra-High Performance Liquid Chromatography system. This system was installed in January, 2020, and began limited operation in 2020 due to partial laboratory shutdowns during the COVID-19 pandemic. Use dramatically increased in 2021 and in 2022 and, as a result, 11 peer-reviewed manuscripts that feature measurements this instrument have been already been published with several more in-review or in-preparation.

This system addresses the need to unravel the complex nature of atmospheric aerosol particles, of which a considerable fraction can be characterized as secondary organic aerosol (SOA). These particles can form spontaneously in the atmosphere by a process wherein volatile organic gases react with trace oxidants in a multi-step mechanism to generate low-volatility products, which then partition into the condensed phase. Assessing the relative contributions of different gases on the formation of SOA in different parts of the world is an important goal of atmospheric chemistry but poses a considerable analytical challenge. These precursor gases can come from a variety of different sources including plant emissions, a source comprised of thousands of identified organic species. Adding to this complexity is the fact that one organic aerosol precursor could yield hundreds of oxidized products due to the free radical propagating nature of the reactions. HRMS is an important tool used for the chemical analysis of organic aerosol. However, progress in this field has been hampered by the often-overwhelming size of datasets generated upon analysis, leaving many compounds unidentified and thus preventing comprehensive source apportionment. Using the system purchased with this MRI, we have developed a new methodology to examine the molecular composition of these aerosols that addresses this challenge by integrating a framework borrowed from the field of metabolomics. Metabolomics is a methodological approach that seeks to define the metabolome (or the complete set of all small compounds, i.e., metabolites) in organisms by providing procedures for all parts of a sample analysis, including those for HRMS data filtering, statistics, and interpretation. One goal of metabolomics is to reduce data complexity by focusing specifically on metabolites and their byproducts (e.g., oxidized derivatives).

Currently, atmospheric chemists can identify and quantify only a very small fraction of organic constituents in the atmosphere, which has led to a large bias in model-predicted organic aerosol.  Our measurements of the unexplored organic constituents in the Earth's atmosphere could lead to improved representation of the aerosol life cycle, which is a major uncertainty in climate models. This instrument has provided opportunities for collaboration between chemists, earth system scientists, and ecologists in studies of the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum and its response to global change. The research made possible by this instrument has also provided training to approx. 150 graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, and undergraduates in cutting edge instrumentation and its application to important atmospheric problems. Historically, our trainees have come largely from underrepresented groups in science: we estimate that 53% of the users are from underrepresented groups in STEM.
